title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement duan@songqi.org. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: ShennongObject: Quick Start Guide
text: ShennongObject package provides S4 class, Shennong, designed storing analyzing multi-modal single-cell bulk omics data. builds upon MultiAssayExperiment framework, offering structured way manage multiple assays (e.g., RNA, ATAC), data layers within assays (e.g., counts, normalized data, scaled data), dimensional reductions (e.g., PCA, UMAP), sample metadata, analysis provenance. vignette provides quick overview creating interacting Shennong object.

title: ShennongObject: Quick Start Guide
code: # install.packages("pak") pak::pak("zerostwo/shennong-object")

title: ShennongObject: Quick Start Guide
text: primary way create Shennong object using sn_initialize_shennong_object() function. need least counts matrix columns represent samples rows represent features (e.g., genes, peaks). constructor automatically calculates nCount_RNA nFeature_RNA adds sample metadata.
code: # 1. Create dummy RNA counts matrix (genes x samples) genes <- paste0("Gene", 1:100) samples <- paste0("Sample", 1:10) rna_counts <- matrix(   rpois(1000, lambda = 10),   nrow = 100,   dimnames = list(genes, samples) ) # Make it sparse for demonstration rna_counts[sample(1000, 300)] <- 0 rna_counts <- as(rna_counts, "dgCMatrix")  # 2. Create dummy sample metadata sample_metadata <- data.frame(   condition = sample(c("Control", "Treated"), 10, replace = TRUE),   batch = factor(sample(c("A", "B"), 10, replace = TRUE)),   row.names = samples )  # 3. Create the Shennong object sn_obj <- sn_initialize_shennong_object(   counts = rna_counts,   metadata = sample_metadata,   project = "QuickStart",   assay = "RNA" # Name for the primary assay )  # Print basic summary print(sn_obj) #> A Shennong object:  QuickStart  #> Organism: NA  #> A Shennong object of 1 listed #>  experiment with a user-defined name and respective class. #>  Containing an ExperimentList class object of length 1: #>  [1] RNA: SummarizedExperiment with 100 rows and 10 columns #> Functionality: #>  experiments() - obtain the ExperimentList instance #>  colData() - the primary/phenotype DataFrame #>  sampleMap() - the sample coordination DataFrame #>  `$`, `[`, `[[` - extract colData columns, subset, or experiment #>  *Format() - convert into a long or wide DataFrame #>  assays() - convert ExperimentList to a SimpleList of matrices #>  exportClass() - save data to flat files #>  #> --- Shennong Specific Slots --- #> Active Assay: RNA  #> Active Ident: 1 levels (first few: QuickStart )  #> 0 dimensional reduction(s) present: None  #> Misc data: None  #> Command history stored: No  #> Tools data stored: None  #> Object created with ShennongObject version: 0.1.0

title: ShennongObject: Quick Start Guide
text: Several accessor functions help explore object’s contents:
code: # Get object dimensions (features in active assay x samples) dim(sn_obj) #> Features  Samples  #>      100       10  # Get sample names (primary sample identifiers) head(sn_samples(sn_obj)) #> [1] "Sample1" "Sample2" "Sample3" "Sample4" "Sample5" "Sample6"  # Get feature names (from the active assay) head(sn_features(sn_obj)) #> [1] "Gene1" "Gene2" "Gene3" "Gene4" "Gene5" "Gene6"  # List available assays sn_assays(sn_obj) #> [1] "RNA"  # Get the currently active assay sn_active_assay(sn_obj) #> [1] "RNA"  # List available data layers within the active assay sn_layers(sn_obj) # Initially just 'counts' #> [1] "counts"  # Get the currently active layer within the active assay sn_active_layer(sn_obj) #> [1] "counts"  # Access sample metadata (colData) head(sn_metadata(sn_obj)) #> # A tibble: 6 × 5 #>   observation condition batch nFeature_RNA nCount_RNA #>   <chr>       <chr>     <fct>        <int>      <dbl> #> 1 Sample1     Control   A               69        716 #> 2 Sample2     Control   B               59        546 #> 3 Sample3     Control   B               81        815 #> 4 Sample4     Treated   A               69        677 #> 5 Sample5     Control   B               67        687 #> 6 Sample6     Control   A               72        696  # Access specific metadata columns head(sn_metadata(sn_obj, cols = c("condition", "nCount_RNA"))) #> # A tibble: 6 × 2 #>   condition nCount_RNA #>   <chr>          <dbl> #> 1 Control          716 #> 2 Control          546 #> 3 Control          815 #> 4 Treated          677 #> 5 Control          687 #> 6 Control          696  # Get the current sample identities sn_active_ident(sn_obj) # Initially set to project name #>    Sample1    Sample2    Sample3    Sample4    Sample5    Sample6    Sample7  #> QuickStart QuickStart QuickStart QuickStart QuickStart QuickStart QuickStart  #>    Sample8    Sample9   Sample10  #> QuickStart QuickStart QuickStart  #> Levels: QuickStart  # Get levels of the current identity sn_levels(sn_obj) #> [1] "QuickStart"

title: ShennongObject: Quick Start Guide
text: can add new assays data layers object.
code: # Add a normalized data layer to the RNA assay rna_normalized_data <- log1p(rna_counts) sn_layer_data(sn_obj, layer = "logcounts", assay = "RNA") <- rna_normalized_data  # Check the layers again sn_layers(sn_obj, assay = "RNA") #> [1] "counts"    "logcounts"  # Set the active layer for the RNA assay sn_active_layer(sn_obj, assay = "RNA") <- "logcounts" sn_active_layer(sn_obj, assay = "RNA") #> [1] "logcounts"  # Access the new layer's data (first 5 features, 3 samples) sn_layer_data(sn_obj, layer = "logcounts")[1:5, 1:3] #> 5 x 3 sparse Matrix of class "dgCMatrix" #>        Sample1  Sample2  Sample3 #> Gene1 .        2.564949 2.772589 #> Gene2 2.564949 .        2.197225 #> Gene3 2.302585 .        2.564949 #> Gene4 .        .        2.079442 #> Gene5 2.397895 .        2.564949  # Create dummy ATAC data (peaks x samples) peaks <- paste0("Peak", 1:50) atac_counts <- matrix(   rpois(500, lambda = 5),   nrow = 50,   dimnames = list(peaks, samples) # Use same sample names )  # Add ATAC assay sn_obj <- sn_add_assay(sn_obj, data = atac_counts, assay = "ATAC")  # Check assays again sn_assays(sn_obj) #> [1] "RNA"  "ATAC"  # Switch active assay sn_active_assay(sn_obj) <- "ATAC" sn_active_assay(sn_obj) #> [1] "ATAC"  # Dimensions now reflect the ATAC assay dim(sn_obj) #> Features  Samples  #>       50       10 head(sn_features(sn_obj)) # Now shows peaks #> [1] "Peak1" "Peak2" "Peak3" "Peak4" "Peak5" "Peak6"  # Switch back to RNA sn_active_assay(sn_obj) <- "RNA"

title: ShennongObject: Quick Start Guide
text: Add new metadata columns easily.
code: # Add a new metadata column (e.g., sequencing depth) seq_depth <- runif(10, 1e6, 5e6) names(seq_depth) <- samples # Ensure names match samples  sn_obj <- sn_add_metadata(sn_obj, metadata = seq_depth, col_name = "SeqDepth")  # Add multiple columns via a data frame extra_meta <- data.frame(   QC_flag = sample(c("Pass", "Fail"), 10, replace = TRUE),   row.names = samples ) sn_obj <- sn_add_metadata(sn_obj, metadata = extra_meta)  # View updated metadata head(sn_metadata(sn_obj)) #> # A tibble: 6 × 7 #>   observation condition batch nFeature_RNA nCount_RNA SeqDepth QC_flag #>   <chr>       <chr>     <fct>        <int>      <dbl>    <dbl> <chr>   #> 1 Sample1     Control   A               69        716 2535378. Pass    #> 2 Sample2     Control   B               59        546 2018978. Pass    #> 3 Sample3     Control   B               81        815 1941314. Pass    #> 4 Sample4     Treated   A               69        677 3888771. Fail    #> 5 Sample5     Control   B               67        687 1809578. Fail    #> 6 Sample6     Control   A               72        696 1702317. Fail

title: ShennongObject: Quick Start Guide
text: Sample identities crucial grouping visualization.
code: # Set identities based on a metadata column sn_active_ident(sn_obj) <- "condition" sn_active_ident(sn_obj) #>  Sample1  Sample2  Sample3  Sample4  Sample5  Sample6  Sample7  Sample8  #>  Control  Control  Control  Treated  Control  Control  Control  Treated  #>  Sample9 Sample10  #>  Control  Control  #> Levels: Control Treated sn_levels(sn_obj) #> [1] "Control" "Treated"  # Stash the current identity before changing it # sn_obj <- sn_stash_ident(sn_obj, save.name = "condition_ident") # head(sn_metadata(sn_obj)) # 'condition_ident' added  # Set identities based on batch sn_active_ident(sn_obj) <- "batch" sn_active_ident(sn_obj) #>  Sample1  Sample2  Sample3  Sample4  Sample5  Sample6  Sample7  Sample8  #>        A        B        B        A        B        A        A        B  #>  Sample9 Sample10  #>        A        A  #> Levels: A B sn_levels(sn_obj) #> [1] "A" "B"

title: ShennongObject: Quick Start Guide
text: Store results dimensionality reduction techniques like PCA UMAP.
code: # Perform PCA on the logcounts data (requires transpose) # Note: Use a dedicated PCA function in practice (e.g., irlba, stats::prcomp) pca_res <- prcomp(t(as.matrix(sn_layer_data(sn_obj, layer = "logcounts"))), scale. = TRUE)  # Create a ShennongReduction object # embedding: samples x dimensions # loadings: features x dimensions (optional) # stdev: standard deviations (optional) pca_reduction <- sn_create_reduction(   embedding = pca_res$x[, 1:5], # Store first 5 PCs   loadings = pca_res$rotation[, 1:5],   stdev = pca_res$sdev[1:5],   assay_used = "RNA", # Record the source assay   key = "PC" # Key for naming embedding columns (PC_1, PC_2, ...) )  # Add the reduction to the object using [[<- sn_obj[["pca"]] <- pca_reduction  # List available reductions sn_reductions(sn_obj) #> [1] "pca"  # Access embeddings (samples x PCs) head(sn_embeddings(sn_obj, reduction = "pca")) #>              PC_1       PC_2       PC_3        PC_4      PC_5 #> Sample1 -2.369298  2.2885778  4.2884253  5.12771130  1.492757 #> Sample2 -2.822969 -8.2420094  0.6995116  0.03317859 -3.944174 #> Sample3  3.142982  3.7630478  0.5326515 -1.31777951  1.007782 #> Sample4  1.133157 -3.2384554 -4.9869765  2.02499747  6.551930 #> Sample5  8.984391 -0.5696358 -2.5700917  1.26921424 -3.433471 #> Sample6 -1.891485  4.8355435 -2.9953940  0.24469486 -3.567361  # Access loadings (features x PCs) head(sn_loadings(sn_obj, reduction = "pca")) #>              PC_1         PC_2        PC_3        PC_4        PC_5 #> Gene1 -0.01063137 -0.010207736  0.12755742 -0.08178136 -0.09328871 #> Gene2 -0.06431963  0.064091104  0.07149680  0.01069776  0.25080270 #> Gene3  0.12171388  0.045484142 -0.02698508  0.08901436  0.13566467 #> Gene4  0.16818524 -0.007597089 -0.01614842 -0.13596567  0.13936078 #> Gene5 -0.10726588  0.179235935  0.03880029 -0.06246617  0.15980643 #> Gene6  0.08796201  0.133319881 -0.09637162 -0.12106184 -0.09259308  # Access standard deviations sn_stdev(sn_obj, reduction = "pca") #> [1] 4.132629 3.733993 3.631563 3.421851 3.213822

title: ShennongObject: Quick Start Guide
text: sn_fetch_data() function provides convenient way retrieve combinations metadata, identities, expression data (active layer active assay), reduction embeddings. concludes quick start guide. Explore function documentation (?sn_initialize_shennong_object, ?sn_add_assay, etc.) details advanced options.
code: # Fetch metadata ('condition') and first two PCs ('PC_1', 'PC_2') plot_data <- sn_fetch_data(sn_obj, vars = c("condition", "PC_1", "PC_2")) head(plot_data) #>         condition      PC_1       PC_2 #> Sample1   Control -2.369298  2.2885778 #> Sample2   Control -2.822969 -8.2420094 #> Sample3   Control  3.142982  3.7630478 #> Sample4   Treated  1.133157 -3.2384554 #> Sample5   Control  8.984391 -0.5696358 #> Sample6   Control -1.891485  4.8355435  # Fetch expression of Gene1 and Gene2, plus batch info expr_data <- sn_fetch_data(sn_obj, vars = c("Gene1", "Gene2", "batch"), layer = "logcounts") head(expr_data) #>         batch    Gene1    Gene2 #> Sample1     A 0.000000 2.564949 #> Sample2     B 2.564949 0.000000 #> Sample3     B 2.772589 2.197225 #> Sample4     A 0.000000 2.484907 #> Sample5     B 0.000000 0.000000 #> Sample6     A 2.079442 0.000000  # Fetch current identity ('ident') ident_data <- sn_fetch_data(sn_obj, vars = "ident") head(ident_data) #>         ident #> Sample1     A #> Sample2     B #> Sample3     B #> Sample4     A #> Sample5     B #> Sample6     A

what: Modern Data Structures for Multi-Omics Analysis
title: Modern Data Structures for Multi-Omics Analysis
text: goal ShennongObject provide S4 class, Shennong, designed storing analyzing multi-modal single-cell bulk omics data. builds upon MultiAssayExperiment framework, offering structured way manage multiple assays (e.g., RNA, ATAC), data layers within assays (e.g., counts, normalized data, scaled data), dimensional reductions (e.g., PCA, UMAP), sample metadata, analysis provenance. design ShennongObject inspired structured API Seurat package single-cell data, draws conceptual influence tidyomics philosophy support tidyverse-style workflows omics analysis.

title: Modern Data Structures for Multi-Omics Analysis
text: install development version GitHub:
code: # install.packages("pak") pak::pak("zerostwo/shennong-object")

title: Modern Data Structures for Multi-Omics Analysis
text: basic example showing create Shennong object: detailed usage, please see package vignettes, starting “Quick Start Guide”:
code: library(ShennongObject)  # 1. Create dummy RNA counts matrix (genes x samples) genes <- paste0("Gene", 1:100) samples <- paste0("Sample", 1:10) rna_counts <- matrix(   rpois(1000, lambda = 10),   nrow = 100,   dimnames = list(genes, samples) ) # Make it sparse for demonstration rna_counts[sample(1000, 300)] <- 0 rna_counts <- as(rna_counts, "dgCMatrix")  # 2. Create dummy sample metadata sample_metadata <- data.frame(   condition = sample(c("Control", "Treated"), 10, replace = TRUE),   batch = factor(sample(c("A", "B"), 10, replace = TRUE)),   row.names = samples )  # 3. Create the Shennong object sn_obj <- sn_initialize_shennong_object(   counts = rna_counts,   metadata = sample_metadata,   project = "QuickStart",   assay = "RNA" # Name for the primary assay )  # Print basic summary print(sn_obj) #> A Shennong object:  QuickStart  #> Organism: NA  #> A Shennong object of 1 listed #>  experiment with a user-defined name and respective class. #>  Containing an ExperimentList class object of length 1: #>  [1] RNA: SummarizedExperiment with 100 rows and 10 columns #> Functionality: #>  experiments() - obtain the ExperimentList instance #>  colData() - the primary/phenotype DataFrame #>  sampleMap() - the sample coordination DataFrame #>  `$`, `[`, `[[` - extract colData columns, subset, or experiment #>  *Format() - convert into a long or wide DataFrame #>  assays() - convert ExperimentList to a SimpleList of matrices #>  exportClass() - save data to flat files #>  #> --- Shennong Specific Slots --- #> Active Assay: RNA  #> Active Ident: 1 levels (first few: QuickStart )  #> 0 dimensional reduction(s) present: None  #> Misc data: None  #> Command history stored: No  #> Tools data stored: None  #> Object created with ShennongObject version: 0.1.0

title: Modern Data Structures for Multi-Omics Analysis
text: Please note ShennongObject project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project, agree abide terms.

what: Show method for Shennong objects — Shennong-class
title: Show method for Shennong objects — Shennong-class
text: Displays summary information Shennong object.

title: Show method for Shennong objects — Shennong-class
code: # S4 method for class 'Shennong,character,ANY' x[[i, j, ...]]  # S4 method for class 'Shennong,character,missing,ShennongReduction' x[[i, j, ...]] <- value  # S4 method for class 'Shennong' show(object)

title: Show method for Shennong objects — Shennong-class
text: x Shennong object Name reduction assign j (Ignored) Required method signature used. ... Additional arguments (ignored) value ShennongReduction object object Shennong object.

title: Show method for Shennong objects — Shennong-class
text: x[[: Assign reduction object name `[[`(x = Shennong, = character, j = missing) <- value: Assign reduction object name

title: Show method for Shennong objects — Shennong-class
text: organism Character string specifying organism (e.g., "human"). active_assay Character string indicating name currently active assay within ExperimentList. active_ident factor representing current identity (e.g., cluster condition) sample object's primary colData. length must match nrow(colData(object)). reductions list storing dimensional reduction information (e.g., PCA, tSNE, UMAP). Typically, element matrix rows correspond samples. recommended store reductions associated specific assays primary sample set. project_name Character string name project. misc list storing miscellaneous data associated object. version version ShennongObject package used create object. commands list store analysis commands history (audit trail). tools list store results generated various tools functions.

title: The ShennongCommand Class — ShennongCommand-class
text: Used log function calls, parameters, timestamps, assay context tracking operations within Shennong object

title: The ShennongCommand Class — ShennongCommand-class
text: name Name command time_stamp POSIXct timestamp command execution assay_used Name assay used (NA set) call_string Full function call string params List parameters passed command

what: ShennongObject: Modern Data Structures for Multi-Omics Analysis — ShennongObject-package
title: ShennongObject: Modern Data Structures for Multi-Omics Analysis — ShennongObject-package
text: Provides tidy, extensible, modular S4 data infrastructure organizing analyzing multi-omics single-cell datasets R. ShennongObject class extends MultiAssayExperiment support streamlined integration assays, flexible metadata management, dimensionality reductions, visualization tools, analysis provenance tracking. Designed compatibility tidyverse-style workflows modern bioinformatics pipelines.

title: ShennongObject: Modern Data Structures for Multi-Omics Analysis — ShennongObject-package
text: Maintainer: Songqi Duan duan@songqi.org (ORCID)

title: The ShennongReduction Class — ShennongReduction-class
text: Stores dimensionality reduction results (e.g., PCA, UMAP, tSNE) Shennong object. Inspired Seurat's DimReduc structure, class contains embeddings, optional feature loadings, standard deviations, naming key, metadata.

title: The ShennongReduction Class — ShennongReduction-class
code: # S4 method for class 'ShennongReduction' show(object)

title: The ShennongReduction Class — ShennongReduction-class
text: object ShennongReduction object.

title: The ShennongReduction Class — ShennongReduction-class
text: embedding matrix sample (cell) coordinates reduced space. loadings matrix feature loadings (optional). stdev numeric vector standard deviations dimension. assay_used name assay reduction computed . global Logical. TRUE, persists across assay removal. key character prefix (e.g., "PC") prepended column names embedding matrix. misc list additional information.

title: The ShennongTool Class — ShennongTool-class
text: Stores results generated computational tool algorithm (e.g., UCell, GSVA, AUCell) applied data Shennong object.

title: The ShennongTool Class — ShennongTool-class
text: method Character. name tool method used (e.g., "UCell"). version Character. Version tool used. result list matrix storing primary result. params list parameters used running tool. timestamp POSIXct. time tool run. status Character. Status run ("success", "error", etc.). citation Character. Optional reference citation tool. misc list additional metadata.

what: Filter samples in a Shennong object using dplyr syntax — filter.Shennong
title: Filter samples in a Shennong object using dplyr syntax — filter.Shennong
text: Allows tidyverse-style filtering sample metadata (`colData`) Shennong object. behaves like `dplyr::filter()`, subsets object retain samples matching specified conditions.

title: Filter samples in a Shennong object using dplyr syntax — filter.Shennong
code: # S3 method for class 'Shennong' filter(.data, ..., layer = NULL, .by = NULL, .preserve = FALSE)

title: Filter samples in a Shennong object using dplyr syntax — filter.Shennong
text: .data `Shennong` object. ... Filtering conditions passed `dplyr::filter()`. layer name expression matrix layer use filtering. `NULL`, active layer used. .Optional grouping variable(s). .preserve Whether preserve grouping structure.

title: Filter samples in a Shennong object using dplyr syntax — filter.Shennong
text: filtered `Shennong` object.

title: Filter samples in a Shennong object using dplyr syntax — filter.Shennong
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ filter(so, stage == "Stage I", gender == "Female") } # }

what: ggplot method for Shennong object — ggplot.Shennong

text: Allows tidy ggplot2 visualization using sample-level metadata expression values.

title: ggplot method for Shennong object — ggplot.Shennong
code: # S3 method for class 'Shennong' ggplot(data, mapping = aes(), ..., environment = parent.frame(), vars = NULL)

title: ggplot method for Shennong object — ggplot.Shennong
text: data Shennong object. mapping Aesthetic mapping (e.g., aes(x = ..., y = ..., color = ...)). ... Additional arguments passed ggplot(). environment environment evaluate mapping. Usually left default. vars Optional character vector variables fetch using sn_fetch_data().

title: ggplot method for Shennong object — ggplot.Shennong
text: ggplot object.

title: Get Default Assay — sn_active_assay
text: Get Default Assay Set Default Assay<-

title: Get Default Assay — sn_active_assay
code: sn_active_assay(object, ...)  sn_active_assay(object, ...) <- value  # S4 method for class 'Shennong' sn_active_assay(object, ...)  # S4 method for class 'Shennong' sn_active_assay(object, ...) <- value

title: Get Default Assay — sn_active_assay
text: object Shennong object. ... Additional arguments. value assay name set active.

title: Get Sample Identities — sn_active_ident
text: Get Sample Identities Set Sample Identities<-

title: Get Sample Identities — sn_active_ident
code: sn_active_ident(object, ...)  sn_active_ident(object, ...) <- value  # S4 method for class 'Shennong' sn_active_ident(object, ...)  # S4 method for class 'Shennong' sn_active_ident(object, samples = NULL, drop = FALSE, replace = FALSE, ...) <- value

title: Get Sample Identities — sn_active_ident
text: object Shennong object. ... Additional arguments. value Identities set (factor, vector, metadata column name). samples Optional: Samples set identities . drop Logical; drop unused identities. replace Logical; replace existing identities.

title: Get the active layer — sn_active_layer

title: Create a Shennong Object — sn_initialize_shennong_object
text: Initializes Shennong object primary counts matrix optional sample metadata.

title: Create a Shennong Object — sn_initialize_shennong_object
code: sn_initialize_shennong_object(   counts = NULL,   assay = "RNA",   metadata = NULL,   project = "Shennong",   organism = character(0),   min_counts = 0,   min_features = 0,   ... )

title: Create a Shennong Object — sn_initialize_shennong_object
text: counts matrix-like object (e.g., matrix, dgCMatrix) containing raw counts. Rows typically represent features (genes) columns represent samples. Column names required used primary sample identifiers. NULL, empty Shennong object created. assay Character string. name assign primary assay created counts matrix (default: "RNA"). metadata Optional data frame DataFrame containing sample-level metadata. Row names must match column names counts matrix. project Character string. Name project (default: "Shennong"). organism Optional character string specifying organism. min_counts Minimum number counts required sample included. Samples total counts threshold filtered . Default 0 (filtering). min_features Minimum number detected features (genes count > 0) required sample included. Default 0 (filtering). ... Additional arguments passed internal new("Shennong", ...) call.

title: Create a Shennong Object — sn_initialize_shennong_object
text: Shennong object.

title: Create a Shennong Object — sn_initialize_shennong_object
code: # Create a dummy counts matrix counts_matrix <- matrix(rpois(1000, lambda = 10), nrow = 100, ncol = 10) rownames(counts_matrix) <- paste0("Gene", 1:100) colnames(counts_matrix) <- paste0("Sample", 1:10)  # Create dummy metadata sample_metadata <- data.frame(   condition = sample(c("Control", "Treated"), 10, replace = TRUE),   batch = sample(c("A", "B"), 10, replace = TRUE),   row.names = colnames(counts_matrix) )  # Create a Shennong object sn_obj <- sn_initialize_shennong_object(   counts = counts_matrix,   metadata = sample_metadata,   project = "TestProject",   organism = "Mus musculus" )  print(sn_obj) #> A Shennong object:  TestProject  #> Organism: Mus musculus  #> A Shennong object of 1 listed #>  experiment with a user-defined name and respective class. #>  Containing an ExperimentList class object of length 1: #>  [1] RNA: SummarizedExperiment with 100 rows and 10 columns #> Functionality: #>  experiments() - obtain the ExperimentList instance #>  colData() - the primary/phenotype DataFrame #>  sampleMap() - the sample coordination DataFrame #>  `$`, `[`, `[[` - extract colData columns, subset, or experiment #>  *Format() - convert into a long or wide DataFrame #>  assays() - convert ExperimentList to a SimpleList of matrices #>  exportClass() - save data to flat files #>  #> --- Shennong Specific Slots --- #> Active Assay: RNA  #> Active Ident: 1 levels (first few: TestProject )  #> 0 dimensional reduction(s) present: None  #> Misc data: None  #> Command history stored: No  #> Tools data stored: None  #> Object created with ShennongObject version: 0.1.0   # Create object without metadata sn_obj_no_meta <- sn_initialize_shennong_object(counts = counts_matrix) print(sn_obj_no_meta) #> A Shennong object:  Shennong  #> Organism: NA  #> A Shennong object of 1 listed #>  experiment with a user-defined name and respective class. #>  Containing an ExperimentList class object of length 1: #>  [1] RNA: SummarizedExperiment with 100 rows and 10 columns #> Functionality: #>  experiments() - obtain the ExperimentList instance #>  colData() - the primary/phenotype DataFrame #>  sampleMap() - the sample coordination DataFrame #>  `$`, `[`, `[[` - extract colData columns, subset, or experiment #>  *Format() - convert into a long or wide DataFrame #>  assays() - convert ExperimentList to a SimpleList of matrices #>  exportClass() - save data to flat files #>  #> --- Shennong Specific Slots --- #> Active Assay: RNA  #> Active Ident: 1 levels (first few: Shennong )  #> 0 dimensional reduction(s) present: None  #> Misc data: None  #> Command history stored: No  #> Tools data stored: None  #> Object created with ShennongObject version: 0.1.0   # Apply basic filtering during creation counts_matrix[, 1] <- 0 # Make first sample have 0 counts sn_obj_filtered <- sn_initialize_shennong_object(   counts = counts_matrix,   metadata = sample_metadata,   min_counts = 10, # Filter sample 1   min_features = 5 ) #> Filtered out 1 samples based on min_counts/min_features: Sample1 #> Warning: Metadata provided for samples not present in (filtered) counts: Sample1. Removing extra metadata. print(sn_obj_filtered) # Should have 9 samples #> A Shennong object:  Shennong  #> Organism: NA  #> A Shennong object of 1 listed #>  experiment with a user-defined name and respective class. #>  Containing an ExperimentList class object of length 1: #>  [1] RNA: SummarizedExperiment with 100 rows and 9 columns #> Functionality: #>  experiments() - obtain the ExperimentList instance #>  colData() - the primary/phenotype DataFrame #>  sampleMap() - the sample coordination DataFrame #>  `$`, `[`, `[[` - extract colData columns, subset, or experiment #>  *Format() - convert into a long or wide DataFrame #>  assays() - convert ExperimentList to a SimpleList of matrices #>  exportClass() - save data to flat files #>  #> --- Shennong Specific Slots --- #> Active Assay: RNA  #> Active Ident: 1 levels (first few: Shennong )  #> 0 dimensional reduction(s) present: None  #> Misc data: None  #> Command history stored: No  #> Tools data stored: None  #> Object created with ShennongObject version: 0.1.0

title: Demo Shennong Object — so
text: compact example `Shennong` object demonstration testing. Includes two assays, multiple data layers, dimensionality reductions, sample metadata.

title: Demo Shennong Object — so
code: data(so)

title: Demo Shennong Object — so
text: `Shennong` object : 2 assays RNA, ATAC 3 layers RNA counts, data (log1p), scale.data (z-scored) 2 reductions pca (via prcomp), mds (via cmdscale) 20 samples metadata condition (Normal Tumor),gender (Male Female),age (integer 40–70) 200 genes Shared across assays

title: Demo Shennong Object — so
code: data(so) so #> A Shennong object:  Shennong  #> Organism: NA  #> A Shennong object of 2 listed #>  experiments with user-defined names and respective classes. #>  Containing an ExperimentList class object of length 2: #>  [1] RNA: SummarizedExperiment with 200 rows and 20 columns #>  [2] ATAC: SummarizedExperiment with 200 rows and 20 columns #> Functionality: #>  experiments() - obtain the ExperimentList instance #>  colData() - the primary/phenotype DataFrame #>  sampleMap() - the sample coordination DataFrame #>  `$`, `[`, `[[` - extract colData columns, subset, or experiment #>  *Format() - convert into a long or wide DataFrame #>  assays() - convert ExperimentList to a SimpleList of matrices #>  exportClass() - save data to flat files #>  #> --- Shennong Specific Slots --- #> Active Assay: RNA  #> Active Ident: 2 levels (first few: Normal, Tumor )  #> 2 dimensional reduction(s) present: pca, mds  #> Misc data: None  #> Command history stored: Yes  #> Tools data stored: None  #> Object created with ShennongObject version: 0.1.0  sn_assays(so) #> [1] "RNA"  "ATAC" sn_layers(so, assay = "RNA") #> [1] "counts"     "data"       "scale.data" sn_reductions(so) #> [1] "pca" "mds" sn_metadata(so) #> # A tibble: 20 × 6 #>    observation condition gender   age nFeature_RNA nCount_RNA #>    <chr>       <chr>     <chr>  <dbl>        <dbl>      <dbl> #>  1 sample1     Normal    Male      42          137       1327 #>  2 sample2     Normal    Female    46          138       1338 #>  3 sample3     Normal    Male      43          128       1290 #>  4 sample4     Normal    Female    68          142       1379 #>  5 sample5     Normal    Male      42          145       1433 #>  6 sample6     Normal    Female    63          148       1527 #>  7 sample7     Normal    Male      61          138       1380 #>  8 sample8     Normal    Female    42          128       1274 #>  9 sample9     Normal    Male      42          140       1374 #> 10 sample10    Normal    Female    48          136       1349 #> 11 sample11    Tumor     Male      67          140       1399 #> 12 sample12    Tumor     Female    40          145       1491 #> 13 sample13    Tumor     Male      48          133       1350 #> 14 sample14    Tumor     Female    46          140       1407 #> 15 sample15    Tumor     Male      60          144       1396 #> 16 sample16    Tumor     Female    67          142       1408 #> 17 sample17    Tumor     Male      57          141       1388 #> 18 sample18    Tumor     Female    42          147       1434 #> 19 sample19    Tumor     Male      57          139       1355 #> 20 sample20    Tumor     Female    42          138       1395
